title: Virtue

articles.content:
“Value” is that which one acts to gain and keep, “virtue” is the action by
which one gains and keeps it.
articles.attribution:
Galt’s Speech,
For the New Intellectual, 121

articles.content: Man has a single basic choice: to think or not, and that is the gauge of his virtue. Moral perfection is an unbreached rationality—not the degree of your intelligence, but the full and relentless use of your mind, not the extent of your knowledge, but the acceptance of reason as an absolute.
articles.attribution:
Galt’s Speech,
For the New Intellectual, 178

articles.content:
My morality, the morality of reason, is contained in a single axiom: existence
exists—and in a single choice: to live. The rest proceeds from these. To live,
man must hold three things as the supreme and ruling values of his life:
Reason—Purpose—Self-esteem. Reason, as his only tool of knowledge—Purpose,
as his choice of the happiness which that tool must proceed to
achieve—Self-esteem, as his inviolate certainty that his mind is competent to
think and his person is worthy of happiness, which means: is worthy of living.
These three values imply and require all of man’s virtues, and all his virtues
pertain to the relation of existence and consciousness: rationality,
independence, integrity, honesty, justice, productiveness, pride.
articles.attribution:
Galt’s Speech,
For the New Intellectual, 128

articles.content: Virtue is not an end in itself. Virtue is not its own reward or sacrificial fodder for the reward of evil. Life is the reward of virtue—and happiness is the goal and the reward of life.
articles.attribution:
Galt’s Speech,
For the New Intellectual, 131

acknowledgement:
Galt’s Speech,
For the New Intellectual, 121
